text:
So hey there, GRRR travelers! Here we are in Shinjuku!
Shinjuku is wow-- it's crazy, there's a

lot of lights, there's a lot of activity... it's
known for being a place with all the
night life, bars and a little bit of a seediness. It's known for one of the biggest red-light
districts in Japan. Shinjuku is known as a red-light district of Tokyo, but you

wouldn't guess it just walking around
because it all goes on "underground". By

day, it's a shopping district and a busy
metro hub, but at night the neon lights

go on and it's a lively and colorful
nightlife district.  Follow the grilled

smoke of izakaya shops at Piss Alley or
try to get into one of the exclusive

members-only bars at Golden Gai. Here's
some things to know and do when you

visit Shinjuku. First up, we have Shinjuku
Station, Tokyo's largest and busiest

metro station. In 2007, it was regarded as
a world's busiest transport hub

according to the Guinness Book of World
Records. It's estimated that over 3.6

million people pass through the station
a day and there are over 200 exits!

So these are the smoking areas in Japan.
That's the first to three story McDonald's

... no! Four story. It's the first four story
McDonald's I've seen!

There.  We're going to go there, next. If
you want to feel like you're traveling

back to post-war Japan, head over to
Omoide Yokocho or what locals lovingly

refer to as "Piss Alley". lt got its name
due to the fact that there was only one

bathroom and drunken locals would
urinate in the alley. It is an alley

lined with over 70 izakaya shops,
seducing you through the aroma of

barbecue yakitori or grilled chicken
skewers. Another specialty of this area is
motsuyaki or grilled animal organs.
You'll see them like, grilling up the food. A lot of bars... for like,  drinking.
A lot of smoke here.
A lot of these shops are like,... close... really tightly knit together, so there's a lot of... just a lot of smoke...

in certain areas.
There's one toilet in the alley and that was it.

That's why it's called Piss Alley. The alley is really
tight, small and smoky so just be aware.  But the
aroma..the smells that come from this joint.  You can smell it...
all that grilled food... makes, makes me a little hungry.

Tokyo has a lot of fun theme restaurant bars- 
the Robot Restaurant is no exception.

It's a live performance with robotic
characters. If you have 8,000 yen to splurge

on nightly entertainment, this spot would
be a great option!

All these lights are insane! One thing
to note about Kabukicho is that it's got its fun

side, it's a partying side, but it's also
got a little bit of its seedy side and you have
to be careful (aka on your toes) around this area.

Next up is Kabukicho, an infamous
district in Shinjuku, where it's rumored

that the streets are run by the Yakuza
or Japanese mafia.  You'll find restaurants and

bars, host and hostess clubs, love hotels
and if know where to look...

adult services. Japan is relatively safe
but one must still be a little careful
here. We're on Kabukicho Sakura dori  and there are a lot of restaurants, lot of bars.. a lot of lights. Bam, look at those lights!
Right now, we're walking down Kabukicho which is known to be one of the shadiest areas in Shinjuku.
You might hear over the loudspeakers, there's an announcement going on...
it's mentioned in Japanese that anyone in this area has to be cautious because there are illegal propositions in this area...

Young men, who proposition you to come into their shops (bars/restaurants) to buy things or eat . 
(Note: It can be a scam to stick you with expensive bills.)
I was told not to make any eye contact with anyone (soliciters) here. Try your best not to stand out and keep to yourself here.
A lot of illegal activities go on here.
In Kabukicho you'll find a healthy amount of host and

hostess bars to entertain and woo lonely
locals. They're like companion bars. No

sexual services are exchanged at these
bars, but clientele will pay large sums
of money to spend time with a host. The popularity of some hosts have raised
them to celebrity status in this area.

The sign says, " My job, my occupation is
beautiful!" There is no stigma in Japan about being a host.
Here in this district, the hosts are actually celebrities.
You'll see on this banner right here, it looks like a boy band...
but it's actually popular hosts.
And even the big screen, they're all hosts.
Reira... Kiriya... Haru... Shu.

Oh wow, okay so right here we're going to
look at a banner of popular hosts of Kabukicho
as well as how much they make.
Ok, so now we are in the area of Kabukicho, which is mostly love motels.

And you'll have different tiers of
love motels. The cost is dependent upon the

hours of stay, anywhere from three to
five hours to like overnight . Some of
them can be pretty kitchy. Some can be pretty lavish and cheesy.
This is one type of hotel facility. (reading) "Short time"...
"Rest"... "Stay". Some of these lovely motels operate

around the idea of secrecy and they will
have-  I guess - services where you don't

need to check in physically.
So this one you can choose it has a
number, so that you can choose which you want to to rent for the evening or the
hour.

Right in the middle of Shinjuku
Kabukicho district you can find Godzilla Road.

.. where a huge Godzilla looks over
the city from the 8th floor of Hotel

Gracery.
Golden Gai is a unique area of six tiny
alleys ... lined by almost 200 tiny bars.
These are all the little bars that they have in this area.
So many.
Golden Gai has several rows. There are little long alleys like this and

then you can cut through... to a little...
squeezy alleys like this!
Walking down here, you can definitely feel the age to it. There are a lot of bars squeezed
together like ... on the row, up stairs...
There's kind of a scent of age to it, actually.

it almost feels like a secret club and
for some bars it kind of is.

There are bars here that cater only to regulars and
then there are bars that are a little

more open to foreigners. You'll be able
to tell what's for foreigners.

Basically by the signs.The rule
of thumb is... if you seen signs in

English, then it's probably foreign
friendly.

See a sign only in Japanese, then there's a
high probability it's only for the
Japanese and locals.

No cover charge, no tax. One drink 800 yen.
There's cover charge ...it's 1000 yen.

So all of the bars here, have their own
separate policy. Some will charge a cover

charge, some won't.
Some will be tax free, some aren't. Some will

allow foreigners, (while) others might only welcome
'members'. So it's best to always look at

the sign, read it and see
if you can meet the requirements.
Right here, we're at Manboo it's a "manga kissaten" or manga cafe.
I actually slept at one of these.
Not at this particular one, but I slept at these.

BAsically, what they are is like
a cafe or an internet cafe for people
who love anime and manga magazines. They have packages that run anywhere from
three hours to five hours... to entire night.

You can definitely sleep here, which I did.
There are facilities that usually have

showers, you know, different options
anywhere from like a recliner chair to

like a little area with your own
computer and a sleeping area. It's kind of

cool and neat and if I have time on this trip I
will probably try and stay in one of these.

Manboo is one of the popular or more
reputable ones.
The quality really ranges from place to place. I can't tell you that, you know...

even know that this is known to be
a fairly good brand, if all of them are high quality.

You have like one night- eight hours. You've got drinks...
hot drinks, free Wi-Fi, comic books.. I guess you can watch movies.
You've got places to charge your battery, you got a shower... I'm not sure what that is ...
I think it's (that) you can sleep overnight you can use a recliner chair..
So these are some of the rates right here.
Three hours is like 900 yen.
24 hours will be (approximately $41 USD)

actually really loved... That's an option

if you're like backpacking on a major
minimal budget. That's what I did... that

is how I did my "$30 a day in Japan" . It's
